meanings.def: to produce flames and heat
examples: A welcoming fire was burning in the fireplace.
Fires were burning all over the city.
A small candle burned brightly.
Fresh leaves will burn slowly with billows of smoke.
The fire was still burning fiercely.
The flame in the oil lamp burned steadily.

meanings.def: to be on fire
examples: By nightfall the whole city was burning.
The girl ran from the burning building.
Two children were rescued from the burning car.
They called us to tell us that my aunt's house was burning.
The smell of burning rubber filled the air.

meanings.def: to destroy, damage, injure or kill somebody/something by fire; to be destroyed, etc. by fire
examples: Six million acres have burned this year in the United States.
The house burned to the ground.
Ten people burned to death in the hotel fire.
burn somebody/something to burn waste paper/dead leaves
All his belongings were burnt in the fire.
The house was burnt to the ground (= completely destroyed).
The survivors burned the bodies of the victims of the plague.
Several protesters burned American flags.
The cigarette burned a hole in the carpet.
Joan of Arc was burned at the stake.
burn somebody/something + adj. His greatest fear is of being burnt alive.
burn + adj. Many were left with no choice but to burn alive or leap to their deaths from the upper floors.
Several people were burned to death.
The building was burned to the ground.
Bishop Tunstall preached a sermon against the book, after which copies were ceremonially burnt.
She burned all his letters.

meanings.def: if you burn a fuel, or a fuel burns, it produces heat, light or energy
examples: Which fuel burns most efficiently?
burn something a furnace that burns gas/oil/coke
(figurative) Some people burn calories (= use food to produce energy) faster than others.

meanings.def: if food burns, or if you burn it, it is damaged by too much heat
examples: I can smell something burning in the kitchen.
burn something Sorry—I burnt the toast.

meanings.def: to be damaged or injured by the sun, heat, acid, etc.; to damage or injure somebody/something in this way
examples: My skin burns easily (= in the sun).
fair skin that burns easily
burn somebody I got badly burned by the sun yesterday.
burn something I burnt my tongue trying to eat a hot meat pie.
The soup's hot. Don't burn your mouth.
His face had been horrifically burnt by acid.
burn yourself I burned myself on the stove.
She burned all his letters.
The house burned down in 1995.
The bodies had been charred beyond recognition.
I scorched my dress when I was ironing it.
He singed his hair as he tried to light his cigarette.

meanings.def: if part of your body burns or is burning, it feels very hot and painful
examples: Your forehead's burning. Have you got a fever?
Her cheeks burned with embarrassment.
My feet hurt.
Ouch! That hurt!
I’m aching all over.
Our eyes were burning from the chemicals in the air.
My eyes were stinging from the smoke.
The cold air made her face tingle.
I itch all over.
Does the rash itch?
His head throbbed painfully.
Her skin seemed to burn at his touch.
Our eyes were burning from the chemicals in the air.

meanings.def: to produce light
examples: Lights were burning upstairs, but no one answered the door.
hot sunshine burning through the windows
Their torches burned brightly in the dark.

meanings.def: to feel or show a very strong emotion or desire
examples: Her eyes burned fiercely.
burn with something to be burning with rage/ambition/love
burn to do something He was burning to go climbing again.
He was burning with indignation.
She could sense the anger burning slowly inside him.

meanings.def: to move very fast in a particular direction
examples: The car was burning down the road.

meanings.def: to make somebody very angry
examples: So you did it just to burn me?

meanings.def: to put information onto a CD or DVD
to spend money
examples: burn something The project burns £2 million a year in contractor costs.
burn through something The state has already burned through its cash reserves.

meanings.def: to do something that makes it impossible to return to the previous situation later
examples: Think carefully before you resign—you don't want to burn your bridges.

meanings.def: to become very tired by trying to do too many things and going to bed late and getting up early
to suffer as a result of doing something without realizing the possible bad results, especially in business
examples: He got his fingers badly burnt dabbling in the stock market.

meanings.def: if money burns a hole in your pocket, you want to spend it as soon as you have it
to study or work until late at night
to drive very fast
to become completely burnt, especially because it has been cooked for too long
examples: By the time I got home, the cake was burnt to a cinder.
The tower was struck by lightning and was burned to a cinder.
I like my steak burnt to a cinder on the outside and blood red and juicy inside.

meanings.def: to go wrong or to fail badly and suddenly
examples: His career crashed and burned after he threatened a journalist.
The stock markets are getting ready to crash and burn.
She continued to crash and burn through personal controversies that included driving drunk.

meanings.def: a person thinks that other people are talking about them, especially in an unkind way
examples: ‘I bumped into your ex-wife last night.’ ‘I thought I could feel my ears burning!’

meanings.def: to have so much money that you do not have to be careful with it

meanings.def: the feeling that you get in your muscles when you have done a lot of exercise
examples: Feel the burn!
